DOC.HEAD: Panamanians Take Arms, Seek Shelter, Food, Medicine
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People took up arms and formed vigilante squads to combat looting and thousands jammed churches, stadiums and schools to flee fighting that has ravaged the capital. Food and medicine were in short supply. As the U.S. military occupation entered its fourth day today, weary and frightened residents stayed behind locked doors to avoid street battles between fighters loyal to ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and American forces. Much of this city of 1 million people was in ruins after air strikes by U.S. warplanes and mortar attacks by Panamanian fighters. Residents in many neighborhoods organized vigilante groups to ward off the looters of homes and businesses who roamed the streets at will. Citizens erected tire barricades and armed themselves for protection against the anarchy, which spread to middle-class neighborhoods on Friday. ``The only way to protect what little we have left is to protect it ourselves,'' said Jorge Perez, a 36-year-old homeowner in the suburb of San Francisco. The city's police, part of the Panamanian Defense Forces, disbanded or collapsed when the invasion began at midnight Tuesday. The three-day looting spree left most businesses and grocery stores depleted of basic foods. Streets were littered with broken glass and trash. Many shopkeepers kept looters at bay with guns. Paying customers who lined up outside the few supermarkets that opened their doors complained of shortages. Motorists looted some gas stations that failed to open for business. Thousands of people fleeing the fighting sought shelter in stadiums, churches or schools. In the city of Balboa, at the Pacific entrance of the Panama Canal, about 3,000 refugees jammed a high school sports stadium. In the capital, 500 refugees were at the Revolution Soccer Stadium, 200 at the capital's Venezuela high school, 100 at another school and 100 more at the Santa Ana Roman Catholic Church. Untold thousands slept in public parks and streets. Many just knocked on stranger's doors and begged to be let in. ``First I fled to a stranger's home. But then I had to leave, and I made my way through the fighting until I was able to reach my mother's house,'' one man said by telephone from his mother's home, where 15 others had taken refuge. A Red Cross official appealed for food donations as shortages of many basics worsened. He noted that many people were donating ``as much as they can spare'' and that many U.S. troops provided rations, but said much more help was needed. Hospitals staffed by doctors and nurses working 16- and 24-hour shifts were overcrowded with the wounded and the dead and ran short of everything from alcohol to analgesics to surgical gauze. ``Besides everything, not only is there no transportation but the staff is scared to go outside,'' said Dr. Elmer Miranda, deputy director of the Santo Tomas Hospital. ``The United States only gives us bullets,'' he said. He complained that supply flights still were prevented from entering Panama because the country's airports remained closed under U.S. military control. Miranda said there were 200 bodies in the hospital's basement morgue. One hospital official estimated there were 1,000 wounded, most of them civilians. One resident surveyed the destroyed building of Noriega's Defense Forces headquarters. Ringed by tanks, the surrounding area remained off-limits to civilians, and U.S. soldiers warned people over loudspeakers to stay away. ``Why did they do this?'' the resident asked. ``Just because they wanted to get Noriega?''
